issues.description: Constructor parameter mismatch between the PersonController implementation in the solution and its usage in the client application. In the solution repository, PersonController only defines a constructor with parameters (String baseUrl, Duration timeout) while H05E01ClientApplication (both in template and solution) instantiates PersonController with the no-argument constructor (new PersonController()). This will cause a compile error and prevents students from running the provided client code. The problem statement and template indicate students should provide a constructor (similar to NoteController's no-arg initialization), so the solution's addition of a parameterized-only constructor is inconsistent with the rest of the exercise.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the PersonController API consistent with its usage. Either (A) add a no-argument constructor to PersonController (recommended) that initializes the WebClient (e.g. baseUrl "http://localhost:8080/", default headers) and the internal persons list so H05E01ClientApplication can keep using new PersonController(), or (B) change H05E01ClientApplication to construct PersonController with the required parameters (e.g. new PersonController("http://localhost:8080/", Duration.ofSeconds(5))). Prefer option A to match the NoteController pattern and the exercise instructions.

issues.description: Typo / parameter type mismatch in the problem statement: when describing the PersonController methods the text says "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter... This consumer takes the internal list of persons as a parameter". The correct generic type for PersonController callbacks is Consumer<List<Person>> (as used in the template method signatures). This mismatch in the documentation may confuse students about the expected callback type.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement text to reference Consumer<List<Person>> when describing the PersonController methods/callbacks. This aligns the textual description with the template method signatures and avoids confusion.
